Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Star Formation in the Magellanic Clouds - Conversion of Gas to Stars at Low Metallicity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative project is to explore the relationship between gas metallicity and star formation rate. It will use the VISTA Magellanic Clouds (VMC) near IR survey photometry to extend a catalog of young stellar objects (YSOs) to solar masses. The program will measure the amount of molecular gas present as a test of recent star formation theories and will ascertain the effects on the structure and formation of dense pre-stellar cores.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoc in the use of ALMA, and release of GPIPS survey results and software to the astronomical community. The Baltimore-based postdoc and graduate students of Dr. Meixner will participate in Project ASTRO, which reaches out to the Baltimore City School system, while Co-I Dr. Indebetouw and his students will create new multi-wavelength components for K-12 teacher workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stars form from the densest regions of gas in a galaxy. Fundamental
questions in astronomy include: how dense does the gas have to be to
collapse and form stars?  Are the physical conditions in dense regions
of galaxies all the same or do they differ from galaxy to galaxy, and
region to region?  This project studied several aspects of those
questions, and in particular, whether the physics of star formation is
different in a galaxy that has a lower concentration of heavy elements
than our Milky Way.  Galaxies in the early universe, for example, had
such lower concentrations, because there had not been as much time
since the Big Bang for stars to create the heavy elements.

The Atacama Large Millimeter Array is an incredibly powerful new
telescope that has given us the ability to study for the first time
the detailed structure of dense gas in galaxies outside of the Milky
Way.  In particular, gas clumps smaller than a few light years in
size, which will form one or a few stars if they collapse, were nearly
impossible to study before ALMA.  The Magellanic Clouds are two small
neighbor galaxies to the Milky Way, both of which fortuitously have
reduced concentrations of heavy elements similar to galaxies in the
early We have studied more than a dozen regions in the Magellanic
Clouds with ALMA, and determined the sizes, masses, shapes, and
internal motions of small clumps of dense gas in those regions.

We find that the basic process by which gravity pulls a cloud of gas
together, causing it collapse and form stars, is not dramatically
different in an environment that has a low concentration of heavy
elements.  This was not a foregone conclusion, because for example,
those heavy elements can dominate the rate at which a cloud can cool
down, and by lowering its temperature and pressure, allow it to
collapse.  We found that different regions have different properties,
apparently mostly due to large-scale influences in their galaxy, for
example one of the Magellanic Clouds is colliding with the far outer
reaches of our own Milky Way, and that disturbance has changed the
amount of dense gas on that side of the galaxy.  We also found that
the observations that astronomers can make are affected by the
concentration of heavy metals - in particular, one of the most
commonly used tools is measurement of emission from carbon monoxide
(CO), and if there is less carbon and oxygen, there is less CO, and it
is more difficult to observe with a telescope.

Figure 1 shows a region N11B, with warm dust in red imaged by the
Spitzer Space Telescope, hot gas in green traced by emission from
ionized hydrogen, and emission from CO in dense gas in white contours,
observed with ALMA.  The concentration of young stars about the same
mass as our sun, extracted from Hubble Space Telescope images, is
shown in blue, and individual young stars much more massive than our
Sun are marked with red circles. In this region, dense clumps of gas
observed with ALMA contain massive stars in the process of forming,
but there is a large concentration of solar-mass stars to the south of
existing dense clumps, indicating that there was once gas there as
well, which has all collapsed to make those stars.
